Jae Hyun Park is a distinguished competitive programmer from South Korea, recognized for his significant achievements in major international programming competitions. With a strong background in algorithmic problem-solving, Park has made notable contributions to the competitive programming community through his participation, coaching, and problem-setting roles in prestigious contests. Below is a comprehensive introduction to his background, achievements, and contributions based on available information.

Background and Education

Jae Hyun Park has a robust academic foundation, particularly in computer science and optimization. He pursued advanced studies at Stanford University, where he conducted research under prominent professors like Stephen Boyd and Andrew Ng. His academic work includes publications in optimization and machine learning, such as “General Heuristics for Nonconvex Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Programming” (2017) and “A Semidefinite Programming Method for Integer Convex Quadratic Minimization” (2017). These works highlight his expertise in convex optimization and algorithms, which are closely related to the problem-solving skills required in competitive programming. Additionally, Park conducted independent research on topics like clone detection in software using graph modeling under Professor Byung-Ro Moon in 2006, indicating an early interest in computational problem-solving.

Competitive Programming Achievements

Jae Hyun Park has an impressive track record in competitive programming, with standout performances in global contests:

  • ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest (ACM-ICPC) World Finals 2010: Park was part of the team that secured the North America Championship and achieved 14th place globally, a significant accomplishment in one of the most prestigious team-based programming competitions.
  • International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI): Park competed under the handle “liszt1990” and participated in the IOI, a premier competition for high school students. His involvement in IOI underscores his early talent in algorithmic problem-solving.
  • Topcoder and Other Platforms: Park is known by the handle “liszt1990” on Topcoder, a platform for competitive programming contests, where he has participated in high-level challenges. His presence on such platforms indicates consistent engagement with the competitive programming community.

Contributions to Competitive Programming

Beyond competing, Park has significantly contributed to the growth of competitive programming through coaching and problem-setting:

  • Korea Olympiad in Informatics (KOI): He served as a coach and problem setter in 2008 and 2012, helping to train and challenge young programmers in South Korea.
  • International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI): In 2013, Park was a student coach for the Korean IOI team, guiding participants to excel in this highly competitive environment.
  • USA Computing Olympiad (USACO): From 2008 to 2011, he acted as a coach and problem setter, contributing to the development of resources and challenges for aspiring programmers in the United States.
  • ACM-ICPC Materials: Park has shared ACM-ICPC-related materials on GitHub, providing valuable resources for students and teams preparing for the contest.

These roles demonstrate his commitment to fostering talent and advancing the field by creating high-quality problems and mentoring the next generation of programmers.

Other Interests and Talents

Jae Hyun Park is a multifaceted individual with interests beyond programming. He is an accomplished pianist, having performed complex pieces such as Gershwin’s Rhapsody in Blue (2015), Kapustin’s Sonata No. 2 (2013), and Liszt’s Ballade No. 2. His musical performances, some of which are available online, showcase his creativity and discipline, qualities that likely complement his problem-solving abilities in competitive programming.

Professional Career

Park’s LinkedIn profile indicates he is a researcher in optimization and machine learning, currently working at a private company in the United States. His professional experience includes roles at major tech companies like Meta (Facebook) and Google, where he likely applied his algorithmic and optimization expertise. His career trajectory reflects a seamless integration of his competitive programming skills into real-world applications in technology and research.

Legacy and Impact

Jae Hyun Park’s achievements in competitive programming, combined with his contributions as a coach and problem setter, have left a lasting impact on the global programming community. His success in contests like ACM-ICPC and IOI, coupled with his mentorship in KOI, IOI, and USACO, has inspired and supported countless young programmers. His academic research in optimization and algorithms further bridges the gap between theoretical computer science and practical problem-solving, a hallmark of competitive programming.
